Legal_Issue: Whether the trademark KELLY ENGINEERING RESOURCES is deceptively misdescriptive under paragraph 12(1)(b) of the Trade-marks Act
Procedural_Stage: Appeal to the Federal Court from the Registrar's decision
Evidence_Assessment: Testimony from Mr. Neth and Mr. McMartin indicating that services fall within engineering practice requiring permits in Alberta
Burden_of_Proof: On the appellant to demonstrate deceptive misdescription
Credibility_Factor: Credibility of witness testimony (Mr. Neth and Mr. McMartin) regarding scope of services
Legal_Rule: A trademark is prohibited if it is deceptively misdescriptive of the character or quality of the associated services
Standard_of_Review: Reasonableness or correctness, as applicable to administrative appeals
Procedural_Issue: Admissibility and consideration of new evidence on appeal
Grounds_for_Claim: The trademark falsely suggests engineering services are provided when non-engineering roles are included
Outcome_on_Merits: The trademark is deceptively misdescriptive and therefore ineligible for registration
Review_Standard: Statutory appeal standard under the Trade-marks Act
Procedural_Fairness_Assessment: Consideration of new evidence not before the Registrar
Key_Evidence_Considered: Nature of employment services offered; professional engineering regulations in Alberta
Applicant_Challenge: Respondent sought registration of the trademark
Defendant_Response: Implied defense of registrability based on literal interpretation or lack of deception
Evidence_Type: Witness testimony, regulatory context, service descriptions
Authority: Registrar of Trademarks (initial), Federal Court (on appeal)
Claimant_Status: Appellant challenging the Registrar's allowance of registration
Applicable_Process: Federal Court appeal process under the Trade-marks Act
Governing_Rule: Paragraph 12(1)(b) of the Trade-marks Act prohibiting deceptively misdescriptive marks
